Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor fit the session into the last hour before boarding a long flight.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Story: I glanced at my phone, the screen lighting up with a reminder: “Mentor session in 10 minutes.” My heart thudded. I was still on the construction site, dust swirling around my boots as the foreman barked out, “Don’t forget to sweep up your area before you go!” The broom felt heavy in my hands, but the weight in my chest was worse. My mentor had squeezed me in for this session, right before catching a long flight. I knew how precious her time was, and I didn’t want to let her down. But the site was a mess, and leaving it unswept would mean risking someone’s safety—and my own reputation as a reliable worker. I could already picture the foreman’s glare if I left early, and the disappointment in my mentor’s voice if I missed our call. I stood frozen, broom in one hand, phone in the other, torn between two worlds that both demanded my best.
